title: Nvidia Endorses Trump’s Plan to Rescind AI Chip Restrictions
summary: Donald Trump's administration is expected to rescind Joe Biden's curbs on AI chip sales as part of a broader effort to revise semiconductor restrictions, Bloomberg reported.Read More
full_text_content:
Donald Trump’s administration is expected to rescind Joe Biden’s curbs on AI chip sales as part of a broader effort to revise semiconductor restrictions, Bloomberg reported.
In a statement, Nvidia said, “We welcome the administration’s leadership and new direction on AI policy. With the AI Diffusion Rule revoked, America will have a once-in-a-generation opportunity to lead the next industrial revolution and create high-paying U.S. jobs, build new U.S.-supplied infrastructure, and alleviate the trade deficit.”
Biden’s restrictions on AI chip sales were reminiscent of the days when the PlayStation 2’s sales were restricted because its processing power was considered close to that of a supercomputer, and that was dangerous if it fell in the hands of those trying to create nuclear weapons.
As such, the restrictions drew opposition from major tech companies and foreign governments, Bloomberg said. The news publication said the repeal is not yet final, but it could lift regulations on the export of chips from Nvidia and others. Trump will reportedly not enforce the AI diffusion rule when it takes effect on May 15. It’s perhaps a coincidence that Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang visited Trump at the White House earlier this year.
Bloomberg said that the change in policy is happening as Trump prepares for a trip to the Middle East, where Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates have reportedly balked at the curbs on their ability to acquire AI chips. Nvidia’s stock price rose in trading today.

seo_agent_results.generated_article_body_md:
## Nvidia Endorses Trump’s Plan to Rescind AI Chip Restrictions The Trump administration is expected to roll back Biden-era restrictions on AI chip sales, a move welcomed by Nvidia. According to Bloomberg, the policy shift aims to revise semiconductor export controls, potentially lifting curbs on companies like Nvidia. The chipmaker praised the decision, framing it as a chance to boost U.S. leadership in AI and create domestic jobs. Biden’s restrictions, likened to past limits on PlayStation 2 exports over supercomputer concerns, faced pushback from tech firms and foreign governments. While the repeal isn’t finalized, Trump’s team reportedly won’t enforce the "AI Diffusion Rule" set to take effect May 15. Nvidia’s stock rose following the news, coinciding with CEO Jensen Huang’s earlier White House visit. ### Policy Shift and Industry Impact The proposed reversal aligns with Trump’s broader efforts to ease trade barriers, particularly as Middle Eastern allies like Saudi Arabia and the UAE resisted the chip limits. Nvidia’s statement emphasized the economic upside, suggesting the change could reduce trade deficits and strengthen U.S. infrastructure. Analysts note the restrictions had strained relationships with key markets, making the pivot a strategic win for chip exporters. #### Pros & Cons
Pros
  • **Economic Growth:** Nvidia argues the policy could spur job creation and domestic investment.
  • **Competitive Edge:** Lifting restrictions may help U.S. firms maintain dominance in AI hardware.
Cons
  • **Security Risks:** Critics warn deregulation could expose advanced tech to geopolitical rivals.
  • **Market Uncertainty:** Rapid policy changes may disrupt long-term supply chain planning.
#### Frequently Asked Questions
What prompted the Biden administration’s original chip restrictions?

The rules aimed to prevent advanced AI chips from being used for military purposes, echoing past concerns about supercomputer-grade tech falling into adversarial hands.

How might this affect Nvidia’s global sales?

With constraints lifted, Nvidia could expand exports to markets like the Middle East, where demand for AI hardware has clashed with recent trade barriers.

Is the policy change confirmed?

Bloomberg reports the repeal isn’t final, but Trump’s team plans to halt enforcement of the May 15 rule.
